Key Discovery Technologies: airborne mag‐radiometrics; geochem sampling; AI targeting
Key Extraction Technologies: open‑pit bauxite; dredge for laterite; red‑mud dry stacking
Key Purification & Refinement Technologi: Bayer digestion; Hall‑Héroult electrolysis; inert‑anode pilots
Key Remediation Technologies: red‑mud dry stacking; residue carbonation; landfill lining
Bottleneck Explainer: Domestic aluminum production is far below demand, requiring imports of both alumina and primary metal. The U.S. has limited bauxite ore and refining, relying on foreign alumina (notably from China/Russia). High energy costs and constrained refining capacity create supply bottlenecks. (O3-Pro speculation)

Key Extraction Technologies: open‑pit & UG narrow veins; planned in‑situ trials
Key Purification & Refinement Technologi: alkaline sulfide leach; electrowinning; Sb trioxide fuming
Key Remediation Technologies: alkaline neutralization of tailings; paste backfill
Bottleneck Explainer: The U.S. has had zero primary antimony mine production for decades, making it ~85% import reliant. Supply depends on foreign sources (mainly China), and processing capacity is limited, causing a critical bottleneck. (O3-Pro speculation)

Key Discovery Technologies: XRF core scanning; EM for sulfide zones
Key Extraction Technologies: by‑product of Cu, Au UG mines
Key Separation Technologies: flotation with Cu; roasting volatilizes As
Key Remediation Technologies: arsenopyrite roasting gas scrub; scorodite stabilization
Bottleneck Explainer: No U.S. arsenic production (100% import reliant). Arsenic is obtained only as a smelter byproduct abroad, and its toxicity has led domestic producers to avoid its recovery, making the supply entirely dependent on imports. (O3-Pro speculation)

Key Discovery Technologies: gravity & mag surveys of SG highs
Bottleneck Explainer: U.S. barite production is modest (only ~25% of demand), forcing reliance on high-density imported barite. Limited domestic high-SG deposits and cheaper Chinese/Mexican sources create a supply bottleneck. (O3-Pro speculation)

Key Discovery Technologies: Remote sensing for laterites; geochem bauxitic profiles
Bottleneck Explainer: U.S. has no primary bauxite production; 100% import reliant into 2030. https://pubs.usgs.gov/periodicals/mcs2024/mcs2024-bauxite.pdf

Key Purification & Refinement Technologi: Be(OH)2 precipitation; vacuum distillation of metal
Bottleneck Explainer: U.S. leads in beryllium but production comes almost entirely from one company (Materion) at a single Utah mine—a single-point failure risk. This domestic monopoly limits supply resilience, as any disruption at this sole source could halt U.S. supply. (O3-Pro speculation)

Key Remediation Technologies: Pb slag reprocessing; slag fuming capture
Bottleneck Explainer: No primary bismuth is mined in the U.S.; supply is a byproduct of lead/zinc smelting abroad. With domestic lead smelting declining, the U.S. relies on imports (about 89% import reliant), mainly from China, so availability hinges on foreign lead production. (O3-Pro speculation)
Cadmium is only recovered as a zinc‑smelting byproduct; limited U.S. smelting constrains supply. https://pubs.usgs.gov/periodicals/mcs2024/mcs2024-cadmium.pdf

Key Remediation Technologies: CeO2 residue disposal; Th cake encapsulation
Bottleneck Explainer: Cerium is produced at Mountain Pass, but the U.S. lacks domestic separation facilities for rare earths. Concentrates are sent overseas (primarily China) for processing. Thus, refining capacity—not mining—is the bottleneck for cerium supply. (O3-Pro speculation)

There are no active cesium mines in the U.S. or anywhere (0 production). Global cesium comes from a few small deposits (e.g., in Canada), and the U.S. must import or draw from stockpiles. The extreme scarcity of pollucite ore is the supply bottleneck. (O3-Pro speculation)

Key Remediation Technologies: chromite tailings thickened; ferrochrome slag reuse
Bottleneck Explainer: The U.S. has zero chromium ore mining, relying completely on imports for chromite/ferrochrome. This total import dependence (mainly on South Africa, Kazakhstan, etc.) is a major supply bottleneck, posing strategic vulnerability. (O3-Pro speculation)

Key Discovery Technologies: mag‑EM for Ni‑Cu sulfides; stream geochem
Key Remediation Technologies: acid drainage treatment; paste tailings; phytoremediation
Bottleneck Explainer: U.S. cobalt output is minimal (mainly a byproduct of copper mining), covering only ~2% of demand. Over 95% is imported or refined overseas. The supply chain depends on the D.R. Congo for mining and China for refining, making U.S. supply vulnerable to foreign disruptions. (O3-Pro speculation)

Key Discovery Technologies: Airborne mag; IP; porphyry alteration mapping
Bottleneck Explainer: Decade‑scale permitting/litigation delays limit new U.S. mines despite demand growth. https://www.futurity.org/copper-renewable-energy-electricity-3220892-2/

No dysprosium is mined in the U.S. Heavy rare earth element (HREE) supply is dominated by Chinese ionic clay deposits. The U.S. is fully import reliant for Dy, so any disruption in China’s output directly creates shortages. (O3-Pro speculation)

Like other heavy rare earths, erbium has no U.S. source. All Er supply comes from Chinese mines, making the U.S. 100% import dependent. The bottleneck is the lack of any non-Chinese production or separation capacity for Er. (O3-Pro speculation)

The U.S. produces mixed rare earth concentrates but does not separate europium domestically. All Eu (a mid-REE) supply comes via foreign separation facilities (chiefly China). The bottleneck is dependence on overseas processing to obtain Eu from mined rare earths. (O3-Pro speculation)
Domestic feldspar covers ~50%; nepheline syenite imports from Canada fill the gap. https://pubs.usgs.gov/periodicals/mcs2024/mcs2024-feldspar.pdf

The U.S. is 100% reliant on imported fluorspar. Despite significant demand for acid-grade fluorspar (e.g. for fluorochemicals), there are no active U.S. fluorspar mines. This complete import dependence (mainly from Mexico) is the critical bottleneck. (O3-Pro speculation)

Gadolinium, a heavy rare earth, is not produced in the U.S. It is obtained from Chinese rare earth operations. The supply bottleneck is the lack of any domestic HREE production or processing, forcing 100% reliance on Chinese exports. (O3-Pro speculation)

The U.S. has no primary gallium production and is completely import dependent. Gallium is only recovered as a byproduct of aluminum/zinc refining, mostly in China. China’s export restrictions on Ga highlight this bottleneck in the U.S. semiconductor supply chain.

Germanium is mostly obtained as a zinc smelting byproduct. The U.S. produces little Ge (about 50% import reliant), since domestic zinc smelting is minimal. Dependence on imports (from Canada, Belgium, China) and the byproduct nature of Ge constrain its availability. (O3-Pro speculation)

The U.S. has 0 natural graphite mining and is 100% import reliant. With China controlling the majority of graphite production and purification, U.S. battery-grade graphite supply is a major bottleneck. Developing domestic mines or synthetic graphite capacity is needed. (O3-Pro speculation)

Hafnium is only produced as a byproduct of zirconium refining, which itself is limited. U.S. hafnium output depends on domestic zircon processing (small) and imports. Any decline in zirconium production directly tightens Hf supply. Lack of primary Hf sources is the bottleneck. (O3-Pro speculation)

Holmium (a heavy REE) has no U.S. source. It is only produced in China as a minor byproduct of rare earth separation. Thus the U.S. supply of Ho is entirely import-dependent, with availability constrained by Chinese production. (O3-Pro speculation)

The U.S. has no primary indium production (100% import reliant). Indium is recovered from zinc ores, but the U.S. lacks active zinc smelters to extract it. This means all indium for LCDs and semiconductors must be imported, a significant bottleneck. (O3-Pro speculation)

Iridium is extremely scarce and only produced as a minor byproduct of platinum mining. The U.S. (Stillwater) yields only ~0.1 t, so >95% must be imported. Global Ir supply is dominated by South Africa and Russia, so U.S. availability is constrained by those sources. (O3-Pro speculation)

The U.S. mines lanthanum-rich rare earth ore (Mountain Pass) but has limited domestic refining. Separated La is mostly processed in China. Although La itself is abundant, the need to ship concentrate abroad for refining is a bottleneck in fully independent supply. (O3-Pro speculation)
U.S. lacks primary Pb smelters; relies on exports of concentrate and domestic recycling. https://pubs.usgs.gov/periodicals/mcs2024/mcs2024-lead.pdf

Despite large lithium demand growth, U.S. production is limited to one brine operation (~5 kt). New projects (brines, clays) face lengthy development and permitting. The U.S. will remain heavily import-reliant for lithium chemicals through 2030, making project development pace the key bottleneck. (O3-Pro speculation)

Lutetium, one of the scarcest rare earths, has no U.S. source. It is only produced in tiny quantities from Chinese ion-adsorption clays. The absolute reliance on Chinese HREE production is the bottleneck for Lu supply. (O3-Pro speculation)

Only one U.S. producer (Utah) supplies magnesium metal, covering ~50% of domestic needs; the rest is imported. U.S. smelters struggle with high energy costs and environmental regulations. Over 50% of global Mg comes from China, making cost-competitive domestic expansion difficult (a supply bottleneck). (O3-Pro speculation)

The U.S. is 100% import reliant on manganese. All Mn ore and ferroalloy are imported (mainly from South Africa, Gabon, Australia). With no domestic deposits in production, any supply disruption abroad (or in proposed seabed nodule projects) leaves the U.S. without manganese. (O3-Pro speculation)
U.S. produces scrap/flake mica; sheet‑grade for electronics is imported. https://pubs.usgs.gov/periodicals/mcs2024/mcs2024-mica.pdf

Neodymium (for magnets) is produced at Mountain Pass in a concentrate, but must be refined abroad (China). Lack of U.S. separation and magnet alloy manufacturing is the bottleneck. Thus, U.S. magnet supply chains depend on foreign Nd-Pr metal production.

Key Discovery Technologies: EM & mag; borehole TEM; laterite mapping
Key Purification & Refinement Technologi: HPAL; matte refining; sulfate crystallization; Electrorefining/matte to Class‑1;
Key Remediation Technologies: paste tailings; SO2 capture; Residue neutralization
Bottleneck Explainer: U.S. nickel production is a fraction of demand (~17 kt vs 100 kt). Over 80% is imported. Moreover, global nickel supply is increasingly concentrated in Indonesia (under Chinese influence). The U.S. lacks sulfide reserves and processing for battery-grade nickel, creating a critical supply bottleneck. (O3-Pro speculation)

The U.S. is fully import dependent on niobium (mostly from Brazil). There are no U.S. niobium mines; a planned Nebraska project is not yet producing. Relying on a single Brazilian supplier (CBMM) for ferroniobium is a major bottleneck and risk. (O3-Pro speculation)

U.S. palladium output (~14 t) comes only from one Montana mine, covering ~70% of domestic needs. The rest is imported, mainly from South Africa and Russia. With Stillwater as the only U.S. source, any disruption shifts reliance entirely to foreign palladium, a significant supply risk. (O3-Pro speculation)
Ample resources, but environmental/permitting constraints limit expansion. https://pubs.usgs.gov/periodicals/mcs2024/mcs2024-phosphate.pdf

Like palladium, U.S. platinum is only mined at the Stillwater complex (~4 t), far below domestic use. The U.S. depends on South African and Russian supply for most platinum. This heavy import reliance, combined with the single domestic PGM mine, is the key bottleneck in platinum supply. (O3-Pro speculation)

Key Extraction Technologies: Solution mining & solar evaporation; UG room‑and‑pillar
Bottleneck Explainer: U.S. remains >90% import reliant (mainly Canada); limited domestic expansion by 2030. https://pubs.usgs.gov/periodicals/mcs2024/mcs2024-potash.pdf

Praseodymium is mined with neodymium at Mountain Pass, but the mixed Nd-Pr product must be separated and converted to metal/magnets overseas. The absence of domestic praseodymium refining and magnet manufacturing is the bottleneck for this critical magnet metal. (O3-Pro speculation)
Recovery tied to Mo/Cu smelters; limited domestic anode‑slimes capture. https://pubs.usgs.gov/periodicals/mcs2024/mcs2024-rhenium.pdf

Rhodium is extremely rare and only produced as a byproduct of platinum/palladium mining. The U.S. yields under 1 t (from Montana); virtually all rhodium is imported from South Africa. Its supply is constrained by the output of primary PGM mines overseas, making availability tenuous. (O3-Pro speculation)

Rubidium has no mine production in the U.S. or elsewhere currently; it is obtained only in trace amounts as a byproduct of cesium or lithium processing. With the U.S. 100% import reliant (mainly on minor Canadian or other sources), rubidium availability is highly limited. (O3-Pro speculation)

Ruthenium is another minor PGM produced only as a byproduct in South African/Russian mines. U.S. output is negligible (~0.2 t), so >95% is imported. The supply bottleneck is dependence on foreign PGM operations for any ruthenium, leaving the U.S. exposed to external supply disruptions. (O3-Pro speculation)

Samarium is present in U.S. rare earth ore, but there is no domestic separation for mid-range rare earths like Sm. All samarium must be recovered overseas (primarily China). Thus the bottleneck is the lack of U.S. capability to extract Sm from mined rare earth concentrates. (O3-Pro speculation)

There are no primary scandium mines in the U.S.; scandium is only recoverable as a byproduct (e.g., from Ti or REE operations). Domestic output is zero and even projected sources (from tailings) are small. This lack of dedicated production makes the U.S. entirely dependent on imports (from e.g. Australia) for Sc, a significant bottleneck. (O3-Pro speculation)
U.S. lacks Se recovery from Cu anode slimes; imports meet demand. https://pubs.usgs.gov/periodicals/mcs2024/mcs2024-selenium.pdf
High electricity costs limit Si metal output vs. demand growth. https://pubs.usgs.gov/periodicals/mcs2024/mcs2024-silicon.pdf
Domestic mines supply <20%; majority from imports despite recycling. https://pubs.usgs.gov/periodicals/mcs2024/mcs2024-silver.pdf
U.S. strontium mining ceased; 100% import reliant (mainly Mexico). https://pubs.usgs.gov/periodicals/mcs2024/mcs2024-strontium.pdf

Key Purification & Refinement Technologi: KOH roast; HF‑H2SO4 leach; capacitor‑grade refining
Bottleneck Explainer: The U.S. has no tantalum mining and is fully reliant on imports. Most Ta is sourced from Central Africa or Brazil. With no domestic production or processing, any supply chain issue abroad directly threatens U.S. access to tantalum (used in capacitors), a clear bottleneck. (O3-Pro speculation)

Tellurium is only produced as a copper refining byproduct. U.S. output is small (Kennecott Utah began Te recovery ~20 t/year). However, over 90% of Te comes from foreign copper anode slimes. If copper producers do not recover tellurium, or if imports from major producers (e.g. China) falter, tellurium supply is constrained. (O3-Pro speculation)

Terbium (for high-performance magnets/phosphors) is not produced outside China. The U.S. has no Tb output and depends entirely on Chinese ion-adsorption clay production. This single-country source for Tb is the bottleneck for any U.S. demand. (O3-Pro speculation)

Thulium is one of the rarest rare earths, produced only in minute quantities in China. With no U.S. production, all Tm must be imported (if available at all). The incredibly low supply (and sole Chinese source) make Tm supply essentially bottlenecked by its rarity and China's output. (O3-Pro speculation)

The U.S. has had no tin mines for decades, making it 100% import dependent for tin. Global tin production is concentrated in countries like Indonesia, Myanmar, and Peru. U.S. supply is vulnerable to disruptions in those regions, with no domestic fallback, hence a critical bottleneck. (O3-Pro speculation)

While the U.S. mines ilmenite mineral, it lacks sufficient domestic titanium sponge production. Over 95% of titanium metal used is imported. High capital cost and environmental issues have hindered new sponge plants, leaving U.S. aerospace and defense supply chains dependent on foreign titanium. (O3-Pro speculation)

The U.S. has no active tungsten mines (last closed in the 1990s), so it relies on imports for ~50% of needs (the rest comes from recycling or stockpiles). China is the world’s top tungsten producer. The absence of domestic mine supply makes tungsten a critical bottleneck for U.S. industry. (O3-Pro speculation)

Key Extraction Technologies: in‑situ leach ash; steel slag reprocessing
Bottleneck Explainer: No primary vanadium mines operate in the U.S. Vanadium is recovered from byproducts like oil refining residues or imported slag. This limited secondary production (~3 kt projected) falls short of demand, keeping the U.S. import-reliant. Dependence on foreign sources (e.g., Russia, South Africa) for vanadium-bearing materials is the bottleneck. (O3-Pro speculation)

Ytterbium, a heavy rare earth, is not mined in the U.S. All Yb supply is from Chinese rare earth operations. Thus the U.S. is entirely dependent on China for Yb, making the supply chain for this element extremely vulnerable. (O3-Pro speculation)

The U.S. has no yttrium production (100% import reliant, mainly from China). Yttrium is obtained from ion-adsorption clays and other rare earth deposits in China. Without domestic production, the bottleneck is absolute import dependence on Chinese sources. (O3-Pro speculation)

The U.S. mines a lot of zinc (e.g., Red Dog in Alaska) but has almost no smelting—its last primary zinc smelter closed in 2013. Concentrates are exported and metal is imported. Thus, domestic zinc metal supply is bottlenecked by the lack of refining capacity, making the U.S. ~80% import reliant for refined zinc. (O3-Pro speculation)

The U.S. produces some zircon (heavy mineral sands), but has limited capacity to refine it into zirconium chemicals or metal. Much of zirconium metal for nuclear and industrial use is imported. Reliance on foreign processing of zircon ore (and import of finished zirconium products) is the bottleneck in the supply chain. (O3-Pro speculation)
